question: Why is the Bhagavad-Gita the perfect theistic science? (1.1)
answer: "It is the perfect theistic science because it is directly spoken by the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Lord Śrī Kṛṣṇa."
open_ai_generated_answer:
Sanskrit Transliteration:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम् |
विवस्वान् मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत् || (BG 4.1)

Translation:
The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: I instructed this imperishable science of yoga to the sun-god, Vivasvan, and Vivasvan instructed it to Manu, the father of mankind, and Manu in turn instructed it to Ikshvaku.

Explanation:
The Bhagavad Gita is the perfect theistic science because it is directly spoken by Lord Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, to Arjuna. In this verse, Krishna explains the disciplic succession of this knowledge, showing that it is not a new invention but an ancient science passed down through the ages. This knowledge is eternal and unchanging, meant to guide humanity in the path of righteousness and spiritual realization.

Srila Prabhupada emphasizes the importance of receiving knowledge through the proper disciplic succession, as it ensures the purity and authenticity of the teachings. By following the instructions of a bona fide spiritual master who is connected to this disciplic succession, one can understand the Bhagavad Gita in its true essence.

Practical Application:
To deepen your understanding of the Bhagavad Gita, it is essential to study it under the guidance of a qualified spiritual master who is part of the disciplic succession. By regularly reading and contemplating the verses of the Gita, and applying its teachings in your daily life, you can gradually advance in your Krishna consciousness.

Encouragement:
Continue your study and practice of the Bhagavad Gita with faith and determination. By following the instructions given by Lord Krishna in this scripture, you can navigate the challenges of life and ultimately attain spiritual perfection. Keep the Bhagavad Gita as your constant companion on your spiritual journey.

question: Why was Dhritarashtra fearful about the outcome of the battle? (1.1)
answer: "Because the battle was arranged to be fought at Kurukṣetra, which is mentioned elsewhere in the Vedas as a place of worship - even for the denizens of heaven - Dhṛtarāṣṭra became very fearful about the influence of the holy place on the outcome of the battle. He knew very well that this would influence Arjuna and the sons of Pāṇḍu favorably, because by nature they were all virtuous."

मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय || (BG 1.1)

English Translation:
Dhritarashtra said: O Sanjaya, after gathering on the holy field of Kurukshetra, and desiring to fight, what did my sons and the sons of Pandu do?

Explanation:
Dhritarashtra was fearful about the outcome of the battle because he was attached to his sons, the Kauravas, who were on the side of adharma (unrighteousness). He knew that the Pandavas, who were on the side of dharma (righteousness), had Lord Krishna as their charioteer, and thus he feared that the victory might go to the Pandavas.

Srila Prabhupada explains that attachment to material relationships can cloud one's judgment and lead to fear and anxiety. Dhritarashtra's attachment to his sons blinded him to the principles of dharma and righteousness, causing him distress.

In our daily lives, we should strive to cultivate detachment from material relationships and focus on our spiritual journey towards Krishna consciousness. By surrendering to Lord Krishna and following the path of dharma, we can overcome fear and anxiety and find peace and fulfillment.

Keep faith in Krishna's plan and continue your devotional practices with sincerity and devotion. Jai Shri Krishna!

question: Describe the significance of the blowing of conchshells on both the sides. (1.14, 1.19)
answer:
-"The sounding of the transcendental conchshells of Krsna and Arjuna indicated that there was no hope of victory for the other side because Kṛṣṇa was on the side of the Pāṇḍavas.'"
-While there was no fear in the Pandava's hearts when the Kaurava's blew their conch shells, "the hearts of the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra were shattered by the sounds vibrated by the Pāṇḍavas' party. This is due to the Pāṇḍavas and their confidence in Lord Kṛṣṇa. One who takes shelter of the Supreme Lord has nothing to fear, even in the midst of the greatest calamity."

Now let us consider the analogy of a drowning man: A man who has fallen into deep water and is struggling to stay afloat is in dire need of help. Similarly, each one of us is in the ocean of material existence, struggling due to our desires and attachments, and we are drowning in illusion (mayā).

In this context, Krishna explains that He is the only solution—the original person (puruṣa) who can rescue us from this predicament. When we come to Him for help, acknowledging His supreme power and wisdom, we will find our way back to Him.

A person in the beginning must simply try to follow the rules and regulations of bhakti-yoga, as they are given in Bhagavad-gita, without desiring any result." (Sri Isopanisad Mantra 1 Purport)

I encourage you to study further verses such as BG 9.34 and BG 18.66 for a deeper understanding of the path of bhakti-yoga and Krishna consciousness, and remember always that with faith and determination in Krishna, you can cross over the material ocean of maya and return to Him. May the blessings of Lord Krishna be with you on your spiritual journey.

Hare Krishna!

-"One who is fully Kṛṣṇa conscious, is called adhyātma-cetās."

-"Nirāśīḥ means that one has to act on the order of the master but should not expect fruitive results."

-"And when one acts in such Kṛṣṇa consciousness, certainly he does not claim proprietorship over anything. This consciousness is called nirmama, or "nothing is mine.""

- "vigata-jvara: without feverish mentality or lethargy."

Bhagavad Gita 3.30:
"Those who know the Supreme Brahman pass away from the world during the influence of the fiery god, in the light, at an auspicious moment, during the fortnight of the moon and the six months when the sun travels in the north."

Explanation:
In this verse, Lord Krishna is describing the qualities of a self-realized soul who is free from material desires and attachments. Let me break down the terms you mentioned:

1. Adhyatma-cetasa: This refers to one who is absorbed in spiritual consciousness, focusing on the self-realization of the soul rather than material pursuits. Such a person is always connected to the Supreme Soul, Krishna.

2. Nirasih: This means being free from material desires and expectations. A devotee who is nirasih does not seek personal gain or gratification but acts solely for the pleasure of Krishna.

3. Nirmamah: This indicates being free from the sense of ownership and possessiveness. A devotee who is nirmamah understands that everything belongs to Krishna and acts as a humble servant, not claiming anything as their own.

4. Vigata-jvarah: This signifies being free from the fever of material existence. A devotee who is vigata-jvarah is peaceful and undisturbed by the ups and downs of material life, as they are firmly situated in their devotion to Krishna.

To apply these qualities in our daily lives, we must cultivate a deep connection with Krishna through regular chanting of the holy names, reading scriptures, and engaging in devotional service. By focusing on spiritual growth and serving others selflessly, we can gradually develop these qualities and progress on the path of bhakti.

Remember, the Bhagavad Gita is a practical guide for living a meaningful and fulfilling life. By following the teachings of Lord Krishna and the guidance of spiritual masters like Srila Prabhupada, we can navigate the challenges of material existence and attain the ultimate goal of life – love and devotion for the Supreme Lord.

Keep studying the Bhagavad Gita and other scriptures, associate with devotees, and always seek the shelter of Krishna. With sincerity and determination, you will surely make progress on your spiritual journey. Stay inspired and continue your service with faith and devotion. Hare Krishna!

-Dust on the mirror is thicker and harder to remove, and this is compared to the lust of animals. Animals are not fit for self realization.

-"The embryo covered by the womb is an analogy illustrating a helpless position, for the child in the womb is so helpless that he cannot even move. This stage of living condition can be compared to that of the trees, because they have been put in a condition of life with a great exhibition of lust that they are almost void of all consciousness."

question: Define "karma," "akarma," and "vikarma". (4.16, 4.17)
answer:
-Karma refers to activities done according to Vedic injunctions (generally referred to as karma-kāṇḍa) producing good reactions.

-Vikarma means activities prohibited in the Vedas which yield bad
reactions.

-Akarma refers to work performed in Kṛṣṇa's service producing no material reactions, neither good nor bad.

question: List any five symptoms of a man in knowledge. (4.19 to 4.23)

3. He is always dovetailed with the supreme desire, for he has no desire for personal sense gratification.
4. He does not make much endeavor even to maintain his body.
5. He is above duality because he does not hesitate to act in any way for the satisfaction of Kṛṣṇa

In the same way, although we cannot go back to Godhead solely by our own endeavors, if we put forth maximum effort with determination, Krsna will be merciful unto us and provide us with tremendous help.

question: The culmination of all kinds of yoga practices lies in bhakti yoga. Explain. (6.47)
